Award.AwardTitle: Cognitive Development Society Diversity Awards October 9-10, 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cognitive Development Society seeks to promote the attendance of young scholars from groups traditionally underrepresented in the field at its 2015 meeting taking place October 9-10 in Columbus, OH. The award will support travel awards to students, post-docs and young investigators from underrepresented groups. To promote networking and professional socialization for these awardees, funds will also support a new mentoring program to ensure a positive and productive conference experience for the young scholars.

The mentoring program will match each young scholar with a more experienced scholar in the field, one with similar research interests. Through an organized meeting at the start of the conference with their mentors, mentees will have the opportunity to forge new professional relationships and broaden their academic network. The young scholars will also be promoted at the conference by being acknowledged during an awards ceremony. Mentors will also support their mentees by attending the young scholars' presentations. These activities are intended to ensure that attending the CDS 2015 conference is a positive and productive experience for young scholars from traditionally underrepresented groups, and to increase the likelihood that attending the conference will yield a positive impact that endures beyond the conference itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cognitive Development Society held its conference in October of 2015 in Columbus, OH.  The society membership as well as attendance at its biennial conference has steadily increased since its inception and first conference in 1999. As the society grows, it has sought to increase the diversity of its membership. To meet this goal, the society requested support from NSF to increase the number of travel awards that the society is typically able to offer to young scholars from traditionally underrepresented groups. In addition, the society wanted to increase the quality of the conference experience for these young scholars from underrepresented groups, ensuring a positive conference that foster developing connections to other younger scholars and established researchers. Funding was thus also requested to develop a mentoring program that paired young scholars with an established researcher who shared their research interests and could enhance the value of attending the conference for young scholars, with the hope that the experience would have enduring impacts on these scholars and more indirectly, to the field. 

Major Activities: With support from NSF, we provided travel awards to 25 young scholars from a diverse array of underrepresented groups. The awards of $600 helped defray the cost of travel, lodging and meals associated with attending the conference. This number of awards represents a significant increase from the number offered in previous years.

In addition, we invited established researchers in the field to serve as mentors. Faculty mentors were typically assigned to two young scholars whose research interests overlapped with their expertise. Mentors were asked to attend a breakfast with the mentees, organized by CDS, on the first morning of the meeting. The timing of this meeting ensured that mentors and mentees would have sufficient time to establish and develop their relationship early in the conference. It also provided the opportunity for the mentors and mentees to discuss their shared research interests. Mentors were asked to attend the young scholar’s presentation. To encourage mentor participation and commitment to their mentees, the mentors had their conference registration fees waived.

Significant Results: Twenty-five travel awards were given to young scholars from a broad range of underrepresented groups.  The impact of the travel award and mentoring program were assessed with an online Qualtrics survey where young scholars could provide their anonymous feedback on the experience. In general, young scholars were enthusiastic about the experience and extremely appreciative of the support. Many of them noted that they appreciated having diversity be broadly defined, going beyond underrepresented groups that are defined solely by ethnic or racial background to also include scholars who are first-generation college and those with a disability.  The survey provided following the conference as well as personal communication noted that all mentors did meet with their mentees at some point during the conference with the majority attending the breakfast. In addition, in nearly all cases, the mentor also attended the presentation given by the young scholar. The mentees noted that this feature of the mentoring program was especially useful and did create a more positive and valuable conference experience. Several of the mentees were optimistic that they would maintain their connection to their mentor, even after the conference.

 Mentors noted that they would be unlikely to complete an online survey of their experiences and instead, were interviewed during brief, in-person interviews during the conference. Similar to the mentees, all mentors were enthusiastic about the experience and felt that the program was an important new addition to the conference. Several expressed reservations with hosting the breakfast so early on the first day of the conference, but conceded that it was useful to meet their mentee at the start of the conference.

The Society also took steps to recognize the young scholars during the conference. The awardees were acknowledged during the awards ceremony, identified in the program book, and their presentations were highlighted as award recipients. In addition, their name tag recognized them as recipients of the travel award. 

All mentees were very appreciative of the financial support provide by the travel award but were especially grateful to have been paired with an established researcher in the field. Interestingly, one mentee was especially grateful that her mentor was Latina, sharing her same background, and expressed a desire to see greater diversity among the mentors.

Several mentees reported that they appreciated that underrepresentation was not limited to ethnic and racial groups but extended to a broader definition, including scholars who were first-generation college. Mentees did express a desire to have opportunities to foster connections among themselves and not just with their faculty mentors and expressed an interest in having additional events provided that would allow time to get to know the other mentees. 

In sum, the mentoring program was successful in broadening academic connections and in creating a more positive conference experience.
